Graphical abstract A Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterostructure demonstrates accelerated sulfur reduction reaction kinetics and excellent electrochemical performance due to the synergistic effect of the three-dimensional porous structure and a built-in electric field. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) offer high energy density and low cost but face challenges such as low sulfur utilization, lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) shuttling, and limited reaction kinetics. To address these issues, we rationally design a Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterostructure with a built-in electric field. This three-dimensional (3D) porous architecture can enhance sulfur loading, facilitate electrolyte penetration, and expose more adsorption and catalytic sites. More importantly, the built-in electric field facilitates charge transfer and directs LiPSs migration from SnS to Ti3C2T x . The oriented migration of LiPSs enables rapid catalytic conversion at the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterogeneous interface, enhancing electrocatalytic activity and sulfur reduction reaction kinetics. The Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode achieves a high initial capacity (1367.1 mAh g−1), excellent rate performance (602.7 mAh g−1 at 3 C), and stable long cycling performance with an average capacity decay rate of only 0.029% per cycle at 2 C. Additionally, a high-sulfur-loaded 3D-printed cathode with loading of 12.7 mg cm−2 manufactured using 3D printing exhibits an areal capacity of 15.0 mAh cm−2, retaining 8.9 mAh cm−2 after 70 cycles. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Shuttle effect Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterojunction 3D printing 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are regarded as one of the most promising next-generation batteries for high theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and impressive energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) [1,2]. Additionally, sulfur, the active material in these batteries, is safe, environmentally friendly, and cost-effective [3,4]. However, LSBs face several challenges that hinder their development and commercialization [5–8]. (1) Sulfur and Li2S exhibit poor conductivity (5 × 10−30 S cm−1); (2) there is significant volume change (up to 80%) during the reaction; (3) lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) are highly soluble in electrolyte, causing a “shuttle effect”; (4) lithium anodes are prone to dendrite growth. These issues severely impact the performance and lifespan of LSBs. To address these issues, numerous strategies have been employed to develop materials that improve the performance of LSBs [9–11]. Among these, the rational design of the cathode structure is considered crucial for effectively adsorbing and catalyzing LiPSs [7,12]. To optimize the performance of LSBs and mitigate the shuttle effect, cathode materials must possess several key attributes: (1) excellent electronic conductivity to facilitate electron transfer; (2) a porous structure that supports sulfur loading and alleviates volume expansion; (3) high adsorption capacity to effectively capture and limit the dissolution and shuttling of LiPSs; (4) high catalytic activity for rapid solid-liquid-solid conversion. Various approaches have been explored to achieve effective regulation of the cathode structure, including the use of porous carbon, metal sulfides, phosphides, nitrides, and oxides [3,10,13–15]. These materials exhibit faster Li+ diffusion and tunable structures that interact strongly with LiPSs, making them widely applicable. MXene with excellent electronic conductivity and adsorption properties shows significant potential for application in LSBs [16–18]. The surface of MXene is abundant in functional groups, allowing it to effectively anchor LiPSs and reduce their shuttling, as well as adsorb Li+ and promote its uniform deposition on the surface [11,16,19–21]. Despite these advantages, MXene exhibits limited catalytic activity, and its few layers tend to stack easily [21,22]. Therefore, combining it with catalytic materials can yield a novel composite with improved conductivity and catalytic performance [23,24]. For instance, Chen et al. constructed a SnS2-MXene composite, which can promote the rapid Li+/electron transfer and reduce the nucleation/decomposition barrier of Li2S [25]. Furthermore, metal sulfides have a good redox catalytic effect on sulfur and are commonly used in LSBs [26,27]. Among them, SnS has a layered structure and good catalytic activity. Meanwhile, SnS has higher electronic conductivity (0.193–0.0083 S cm−1) than SnS2 (10−4–10−6 S cm−1) [28–30]. Yao et al. synthesized ZnS-SnS@NC by leveraging the strong adsorption and high conductivity of SnS alongside the excellent catalytic ability of ZnS [31]. This combination ensured effective electron transfer and enabled uniform lithium deposition. However, conventional bonding alone is insufficient to address the challenges of slow reaction kinetics and LiPSs shuttling. The binding strength between materials can be enhanced by forming heterostructures, which improves catalytic activity. The formation of a built-in electric field can accelerate charge transfer, enhancing the adsorption and catalytic performance of the materials [32,33]. Therefore, combining MXene with SnS to form a heterostructure as a sulfur host presents a highly desirable cathode material. In this study, a Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterostructure with a built-in electric field is rationally constructed by in-situ growth of SnS on the surface of Ti3C2T x . It features a three-dimensional (3D) porous structure that enhances sulfur loading and electrolyte penetration, while also preventing stacking and exposing more active sites. Furthermore, the formation of a built-in electric field promotes charge transfer and ion diffusion, facilitates the migration of LiPSs, inhibits their dissolution, and improves the adsorption and anchoring capacity of LiPSs. Meanwhile, the oriented migration of LiPSs enables rapid catalytic transformation at the heterogeneous interface, demonstrating a synergistic effect between adsorption and catalysis, which further boosts electrocatalytic activity and accelerates the reaction kinetics of LiPSs. The Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode exhibits a high initial capacity of 1367.1 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, excellent rate capability (602.7 mAh g−1 at 3 C), and stable long-cycle performance with a capacity retention of 85.6% after 500 cycles at 2 C. Additionally, a high-sulfur-loaded 3D-printed cathode with a mass loading of 12.7 mg cm−2 is manufactured using 3D printing technology, maintaining a high areal capacity of 8.9 mAh cm−2 after 70 cycles. 2 Experimental section The details of experiments and characterizations are described in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis process of the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterojunction is shown in Fig. 1 (a). Firstly, Ti3AlC2 is etched using LiF and HCl, followed by ultrasonic exfoliation to obtain a few-layer Ti3C2T x . Subsequently, the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterojunction is formed by in-situ growth of SnS on the surface of Ti3C2T x , followed by an annealing treatment at 500 °C. The composition and chemical states in the Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS samples are analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In Fig. S1(a), the XPS spectra reveal distinct signal peaks for O, Sn, Ti, C, and S elements in the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure, confirming the presence of Ti3C2T x and SnS. Fig. 1(b) shows the high-resolution Ti 2p spectrum of Ti3C2T x /SnS, which displays two pairs of peaks at 455.8/461.7 and 458.6/464.3 eV, corresponding to Ti–C and Ti–O bonds, respectively [34]. The Ti–O bonds are formed due to the slight oxidation of Ti3C2T x . When comparing the Ti 2p spectrum of Ti3C2T x , the binding energies of Ti–C and Ti–O bonds in Ti3C2T x /SnS are increased by 0.1–0.9 eV. This suggests that after the formation of the heterostructure, the Ti element may have experienced electron loss, resulting in a decrease in electron cloud density, which enhances the adsorption of LiPSs and improves their anchoring. Subsequently, the C 1s spectra (Fig. S1b) reveal the presence of Ti–C bonds (281.6 eV), C–C bonds (284.8 eV), C–O bonds (286.3 eV), and C=O bonds (288.1 eV) in Ti3C2T x /SnS [35,36]. Compared to Ti3C2T x , Ti3C2T x /SnS exhibits an increased amount of C–O bonds, arising from the decomposition of C=O under high-temperature annealing. Additionally, the Ti–C bonds in Ti3C2T x /SnS are weaker than those in Ti3C2T x , also attributed to oxidation. In the O 1s spectrum of Ti3C2T x /SnS (Fig. S1c), the peak at 530 eV corresponds to the Ti–O bond [37]. The peak at 531.5 eV belongs to C–Ti–OH, which comes from the functional groups on the surface of Ti3C2T x [38]. This favors the chemisorption of LiPSs and helps limit their shuttling effect. The O 1s spectrum of Ti3C2T x exhibits similar peak signals. In Fig. 1(c), the Sn 3d spectrum of Ti3C2T x /SnS displays four peaks. The peaks at 485.4 and 493.8 eV correspond to Sn2+ 3d 5/2 and Sn2+ 3d 3/2, while the peaks at 486.6 and 495.0 eV belong to Sn4+ 3d 5/2 and Sn4+ 3d 3/2 [28,29]. The presence of Sn4+ is due to the oxidation of SnS. Comparing the Sn 3d spectrum of Ti3C2T x /SnS with that of SnS, it can be found that the binding energies for both Sn2+ and Sn4+ in Ti3C2T x /SnS are reduced by 0.2 eV. This reduction indicates that, upon formation of the heterojunction, the Sn element acquires electrons, resulting in an increased electron cloud density, which can enhance the catalytic conversion of LiPSs from solid to liquid and solid states and accelerate the reaction kinetics. In Fig. 1(d), the S 2p spectrum of Ti3C2T x /SnS reveals three peaks at 161.4, 162.8, and 169.0 eV, related to S2− 2p 3/2, S2− 2p 1/2, and satellite peak, respectively [39,40]. In comparison to the S 2p spectrum of SnS, the binding energies for S2− 2p 3/2 and S2− 2p 1/2 in Ti3C2T x /SnS decrease by 0.2 and 0.5 eV, respectively, indicating that the S element also gains electrons and experiences an increase in electron cloud density. Analyzing the Ti 2p and Sn 3d spectral analysis together reveals that during the formation of the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterojunction, Ti3C2T x loses electrons, resulting in a decrease in its electron cloud density, while SnS gains electrons, leading to an increase in its electron cloud density. The electron transfer from Ti3C2T x to SnS indicates the formation of a built-in electric field directed from Ti3C2T x to SnS, which facilitates charge transfer and electron transport, thereby accelerating the catalytic conversion of sulfur to Li2S/Li2S2. Fig. S2(a) shows the Mott-Schottky curves of SnS at 500 and 2000 Hz. By extending the slopes near 0 V and finding their intersection, we determine the conduction band (E C) of SnS to be −1.55 eV. Similarly, the valence band (E V) of SnS is measured to be −0.14 eV using the valence band spectrum from XPS, as depicted in Fig. S2(b). Subsequently, the work function (Φ) of the sample can be calculated by the relationship ΔV = Φ − φ, where φ represents the work function of the XPS instrument and ΔV (contact potential difference) is the difference between the two inflection points of the valence band spectrum from XPS [41,42]. As shown in Fig. S2(c, d), ΔV is 1.27 eV for Ti3C2T x and 1.90 eV for SnS, leading to calculated values of Φ being 5.47 eV for Ti3C2T x and 6.10 eV for SnS. Based on the above results, the electronic energy band structures of Ti3C2T x and SnS are depicted in Fig. 1(e). Ti3C2T x exhibits a lower Φ and a higher Fermi energy level (E F), while SnS shows a higher Φ and a lower E F. When Ti3C2T x and SnS come into contact, electrons are spontaneously transferred from Ti3C2T x to SnS until the E F on both sides reach equilibrium, forming a Mott-Schottky junction. During this process, the bending of the E V and E C occurs, leading to a self-driven redistribution around the heterogeneous interface along the positively charged Ti3C2T x toward the negatively charged SnS. This leads to the generation of a built-in electric field directed from Ti3C2T x toward SnS, which can enhance electron transport and ion diffusion, promoting the directional migration of negatively charged LiPSs from the negatively charged SnS to the positively charged Ti3C2T x . This suggests that the generated LiPSs can be prevented from dissolving into the electrolyte, which enhances their adsorption and anchoring capabilities, thereby significantly suppressing the LiPSs shuttling. In the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Ti3C2T x /SnS in Fig. 2 (a), the diffraction peaks at 22.0°, 26.0°, 27.4°, 30.4°, 31.5°, 31.9°, and 39.0° correspond to the (1 1 0), (1 2 0), (0 2 1), (1 0 1), (1 1 1), (0 4 0), and (1 3 1) planes of SnS, respectively. These peaks align well with the XRD pattern of pure SnS and the standard card of SnS (JCPDS No. 33-1375) [31]. In addition, the diffraction peak at 25.2° belongs to TiO2, which results from the slight oxidation of Ti3C2T x during hydrothermal and high-temperature annealing. The diffraction peaks of Ti3C2T x in Ti3C2T x /SnS are very weak and not significant, due to the low amount of Ti3C2T x in Ti3C2T x /SnS. Fig. 2(b) shows the Raman spectra of Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS. In the Raman spectra of Ti3C2T x /SnS, the peaks located at 155 and 630 cm−1 are related to the Eg mode of Ti3C2T x , while the peaks at 90 and 223 cm−1 correspond to the Ag mode of SnS. The characteristic Raman peaks in Ti3C2T x /SnS shift slightly to lower wavenumbers compared to those of Ti3C2T x and SnS. This shift is mainly due to the strong out-of-plane vibrations induced by the internal electric field force. Fig. 2(c) shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the materials. Ti3C2T x /SnS exhibits an adsorption hysteresis loop with type-IV isotherm, indicating the mesopores in Ti3C2T x /SnS, which can enhance the sulfur loading and electrolyte penetration. Ti3C2T x /SnS demonstrates a higher specific surface area of 41.39 m2 g−1 than Ti3C2T x (12.83 m2 g−1) and SnS (18.22 m2 g−1). Besides, Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS demonstrate average pore sizes of 6.3, 2.0, and 5.1 nm, respectively (Fig. S3). The presence of numerous pores is beneficial for confining LiPSs and accelerating ion transport. The pure SnS (Fig. S4a–c) is composed of numerous nanoflakes, while Ti3C2T x illustrates a large-size two-dimensional (2D) material with a smooth surface (Fig. S5a). From the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images in Fig. 2(d) and Fig. S5(b–f), the Ti3C2T x /SnS features many nanosheets adhered to its surface, exhibiting a petal-like morphology. Additionally, the interior contains numerous large pores, creating a three-dimensional (3D) porous structure. In the transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of Ti3C2T x /SnS (Fig. S6a–c), the larger nanosheets with a lighter color in the lower layer correspond to Ti3C2T x , while the smaller and darker nanoflakes in the upper layer represent SnS. The combination of Ti3C2T x and SnS is tight and uniformly dispersed. Fig. 2(e) presents an high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image that verifies the presence of a Ti3C2T x /SnS heterogeneous interface. In Fig. 2(f, g), the lattice spacings on both sides of the heterogeneous interface are 0.255 and 0.235 nm, which correspond to Ti3C2T x (1 0 2) plane and SnS (1 4 0) plane, respectively. The lattice stripe spacing near the heterogeneous interface is shown in Fig. S7(b). Two different lattice fringes can be clearly observed, belonging to Ti3C2T x and SnS, respectively. Their lattice fringe spacing matches the results presented in Fig. 2(f, g). The presence of this heterostructure interface may promote the diffusion of LiPSs from SnS to Ti3C2T x and the conversion of LiPSs, thus enhancing the sulfur reduction reaction kinetics. Furthermore, Fig. 2(h–l) presents the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) images, revealing the even distribution of Ti, C, Sn, and S elements in Ti3C2T x /SnS. To evaluate the adsorption property of the sulfur hosts, 15 mg of Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS powders are separately added to a prepared Li2S6 solution (Fig. 3 a). Due to the lightweight nature of Ti3C2T x /SnS, some particles tend to remain suspended in the solution, resulting in a black color. After 30 min, the solution containing Ti3C2T x /SnS becomes transparent. This suggests that the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure can effectively adsorb the Li2S6 in the solution and may have a strong interaction with the soluble LiPSs. In contrast, the solution containing either Ti3C2T x or SnS alone retains a distinct yellow color, signifying the presence of un-adsorbed Li2S6 and indicating poor adsorption properties for both materials. Furthermore, the upper solutions after adsorption are subjected to ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectroscopy, with results presented in Fig. 3(b). The solution with Ti3C2T x /SnS exhibits the lowest adsorption intensity of Li2S6, confirming that the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure demonstrates the strongest adsorption capacity. Subsequently, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are performed (Fig. S8), revealing that the binding energies of all Ti3C2T x /SnS and Li2S x are significantly higher than those of SnS. This suggests that Ti3C2T x /SnS and LiPSs exhibit stronger chemical interactions, which is consistent with the results of the adsorption experiments. To explore the catalytic impact of the heterostructure on the LiPSs conversion process, Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS are assembled to conduct electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests. The loadings of the electrocatalyst materials are 0.5–0.7 mg cm−2 (Supporting Information Section 4.4). In Fig. 3(c), the EIS plots of Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS all display two semicircles. This phenomenon occurs because the symmetric cell forms a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film during rest, resulting in an additional semicircle. The first semicircle represents the internal resistance of the SEI film, while the second semicircle corresponds to the charge transfer impedance. The Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure exhibits the lowest charge transfer impedance, indicating a faster charge transfer rate, attributed to its 3D porous conductive structure and built-in electric field. Subsequently, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of the Ti3C2T x /SnS symmetric cells are performed at scan rates of 2–10 mV s−1 (Fig. 3d). The CV curves maintain a stable shape and exhibit two pairs of redox peaks with increasing scan rates, demonstrating excellent electrochemical stability and reversibility. Fig. 3(e) shows a comparison of the CV curves for Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS symmetric cells at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. Ti3C2T x /SnS displays four distinct oxidation and reduction peaks. Ti3C2T x has a lower current and a reduced catalytic ability for LiPSs compared to Ti3C2T x /SnS. Meanwhile, SnS depicts only one pair of obvious peaks with a low peak current. Driven by the built-in electric field in the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure, the LiPSs trapped in SnS can easily migrate toward the interior of the heterojunction. This directional migration of LiPSs facilitates rapid catalytic conversion at the heterojunction, resulting in excellent redox conversion and catalytic activity. The formation mechanism of Li2S is analyzed through a constant potential discharge test. The loading of the electrocatalyst material is the same as that of the symmetric cell (Supporting Information Section 4.5). Fig. 3(f–h) shows the experimental curves of Li2S deposition for Ti3C2T x /SnS, Ti3C2T x , and SnS. The deposition capacities of Li2S are 127.0 mAh g−1 for Ti3C2T x /SnS, 62.6 mAh g−1 for Ti3C2T x , and 69.0 mAh g−1 for SnS, indicating that Li2S deposition is more favorable on Ti3C2T x /SnS. Furthermore, the reaction time for Li2S deposition on Ti3C2T x /SnS is 340 s and the highest current peak is 0.77 mA, which is faster and higher compared to Ti3C2T x (371 s and 0.38 mA) and SnS (391 s and 0.39 mA). Subsequently, constant potential charging tests are conducted to investigate the conversion of solid Li2S into soluble LiPSs and to assess the impact of different samples on the dissolution of Li2S, as shown in Fig. S9(a–c). The Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure exhibits the fastest dissolution response time (480 s) and the highest dissolution current peak (1.06 mA) compared to Ti3C2T x (536 s and 0.63 mA) and SnS (532 s and 0.86 mA). Additionally, the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure demonstrates the highest dissolution capacity (227.1 mAh g−1) compared to Ti3C2T x (155.3 mAh g−1) and SnS (161.6 mAh g−1). Thus, Ti3C2T x /SnS facilitates a faster liquid-solid transition of LiPSs due to the heterostructure and built-in electric field. The Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure is utilized as a sulfur host to obtain Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode for LSBs. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results (Fig. S10) show that the S content of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S composites is 69.6, 69.7, and 69.5 wt%, respectively. CV tests are performed using Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S electrode sheets with the same sulfur loading of 0.8 mg cm−2. Fig. 4 (a–c) presents the contour plots of the CV curves for the Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S electrodes at various scan rates from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1. At the same peak positions, the peak currents for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S are significantly higher than those for Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S. The CV curves at various scan rates (Fig. S11a–c) show that Ti3C2T x /SnS/S maintains four distinct redox peaks and a consistent CV curve shape across varying scan rates. In contrast, the two oxidation peaks of Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S gradually merge into one as the scan rate increases, causing considerable changes in the shape of their CV curves. Furthermore, the shifts observed in Peak I, II, and III for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S at 0.1 and 0.5 mV s−1 are 0.079, 0.022, and 0.07 V, which are significantly smaller than those for Ti3C2T x /S (0.095, 0.058, and 0.091 V) and SnS/S (0.223, 0.124, and 0.184 V). The relationship between the peak current and the square root of scan rate for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S at different redox peak positions is illustrated in Fig. 4(d–f). Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates the highest peak current and superior catalytic conversion performance. Additionally, the slopes for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S at various peak positions are significantly larger than those for Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S. (1) I P = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 AD L i + 1 / 2 v 1 / 2 C L i + The ion diffusion coefficients (D Li+) of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S can be calculated according to Eq. (1) [39,43], where C Li+, v, A, n, and I p represent the Li+ concentration, scan rate, electrode area, number of electrons involved in the reaction, and peak current, respectively. The results, presented in Table S1, indicate that the Li+ diffusion coefficients for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S are greater than those for Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S at Peak I, II, and III. This improvement may be ascribed to the 3D porous conductive structure and built-in electric field, which allows Ti3C2T x /SnS/S to exhibit the fastest ion diffusion and electron transfer rates, effectively enhancing the redox kinetics throughout the discharging and charging process. Subsequently, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) is performed by charging or discharging at 0.1 C for 20 min to measure the closed-circuit voltage (CCV), followed by a 20-min rest period to acquire the open-circuit voltage (QOCV). Fig. 4(g–i) shows the GITT curves of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S. The proportion of Li2S nucleation time to the total discharge time is 25.15% for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, 25.35% for Ti3C2T x /S, and 28.07% for SnS/S, respectively. In Fig. S12, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits longer charge/discharge time and better performance [43]. This suggests that the 3D porous conducting structure and built-in electric field in the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure can enhance charge transfer and ion diffusion. Fig. 5 (a) displays the CV comparison plots for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S at 0.1 mV s−1. Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits four distinct redox peaks, labeled as Peak I, II, III, and IV. The CV curves of Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S exhibit similar redox peaks and reaction processes; however, Peak I and II for both electrodes are not distinct. Additionally, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates stronger peak currents of 3.89, 0.81, and 3.34 A g−1 at Peak I, III, and IV than those observed for Ti3C2T x /S (1.21, 0.37, and 1.72 A g−1) and SnS/S (1.51, 0.61, and 1.66 A g−1). This indicates that Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits higher catalytic activity toward LiPSs with faster reaction kinetics, attributed to the built-in electric field and heterogeneous interfaces. The voltage differences between Peak I and III for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S are measured, yielding ΔE1 of 0.269 V, ΔE2 of 0.337 V, and ΔE3 of 0.473 V, respectively. Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits the smallest voltage difference, indicating the lowest polarization. Fig. 5(b) shows the EIS plots of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S. The fits to the EIS data are shown in Fig. S13. The values of contact resistance of the electrolyte and electrode (R s) for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S are 1.26, 2.06, and 1.58 Ω, and the values of interfacial charge transfer resistance (R ct) are 66.9, 88.7, and 148.9 Ω. Ti3C2T x /SnS/S offers the dual advantage of minimized interfacial impedance and the fastest charge transfer. After 50 cycles, the impedance of the cell decreases due to the penetration of the electrolyte (Fig. S14). Notably, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S still exhibits the lowest resistance. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode exhibits capacities of 1353.0, 1025.2, 840.3, 729.7, 698.3, 662.9, and 602.7 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, and 3 C, respectively. Notably, even at 3 C, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S still maintains a capacity of 602.7 mAh g−1, which is significantly higher than that of Ti3C2T x /S and SnS/S. Then, when the current density is reduced to 0.2 C, the capacity of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S can recover to 921.4 mAh g−1, achieving a capacity retention of 89.9%. Furthermore, in Fig. S15(a), Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates a distinct charging/discharging plateau across various rates. This is particularly evident even at 3 C, where it maintains a longer discharge plateau and a larger discharge capacity. Subsequently, the discharging-charging curves of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S at 0.1 C for the first cycle are compared (Fig. 5d). All curves exhibit two plateaus corresponding to the solid-liquid-solid reaction process. Among them, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates the highest discharge capacity. Additionally, the voltage difference (ΔE) between the two most pronounced charging and discharging plateaus reflects the polarization magnitude of the cell, as shown in Fig. S15(b). The ΔE value is 134.6, 135.2, and 155.4 mV for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S, respectively. Consistent with the CV results at 0.1 mV s−1, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits the lowest polarization. Fig. S15(c) shows the values of the phase conversion coefficients (Q 2/Q 1) for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S. The Q 2/Q 1 value for Ti3C2T x /SnS/S (2.71) is higher than that for Ti3C2T x /S (2.66) and SnS/S (2.46). Here, Q 1 represents the first discharge plateau, corresponding to the solid-liquid transformation process, while Q 2 denotes the second discharge platform, corresponding to the liquid-solid transformation process. These results indicate that Ti3C2T x /SnS can effectively improve the utilization of sulfur. In Fig. 5(e), Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S demonstrate initial capacities of 1367.1, 1112.1, and 1210.2 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, respectively. After 100 cycles, Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, Ti3C2T x /S, and SnS/S maintain capacity of 832.2, 668.9, and 679.3 mAh g−1, respectively. Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates superior performance with a Coulombic efficiency close to 100%. Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits an initial capacity of 800.0 mAh g−1 at 1 C and maintains a reversible capacity of 597.8 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 5f), resulting in a capacity retention rate of 74.7% and an average capacity decay rate of 0.05% per cycle. In contrast, Ti3C2T x /S demonstrates an initial capacity of 556.6 mAh g−1 and a reversible capacity of 232.1 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles. SnS/S exhibits an initial capacity of 658.3 mAh g−1 and a reversible capacity of 376.4 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, resulting in a capacity retention of only 57.2%. The cycling performance of Ti3C2T x and SnS that are physically mixed and loaded with sulfur at 1 C is tested (Fig. S16). After 200 cycles, it exhibits a capacity of only 464.5 mAh g−1, which is inferior to that of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S, indicating that the heterogeneous structure improves the performance of the cell. SEM images of the lithium anode (Fig. S17) after 100 cycles at 1 C are compared. It is evident that Ti3C2T x /SnS/S shows the least amount of lithium dendrite formation on the surface of the lithium anode. This observation indicates that the heterogeneous interface and the built-in electric field effectively adsorb LiPSs and prevent their shuttling, thereby reducing the growth of lithium dendrites. Ultimately, this leads to improved cycling stability of the battery. When discharged at 2 C (Fig. 5g), Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates an initial capacity of 687.3 mAh g−1 and a capacity of 588.4 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, with a capacity retention of 85.6% and an average capacity decay rate as low as 0.029% per cycle. Compared to the recently published MXene-based composite sulfur cathode materials (Table S2), Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits the lowest capacity decay rate at higher current densities. The excellent cycling performance of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S can be attributed to the synergistic effects of adsorption and catalysis facilitated by the built-in electric field and heterogeneous interfaces. To further assess the performance of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S in practical applications, we investigate its performance at high sulfur loading. Typically, high loadings are achieved by applying a thicker electrode slurry onto aluminum foil. However, this method complicates electrolyte penetration within the electrode, preventing sulfur in the innermost layer from participating in the electrochemical reaction. This leads to the loss of active material, low sulfur utilization, and limited performance at high loadings [10,44,45]. This issue can be addressed using 3D-printed electrodes manufactured through a 3D printing technology [46,47]. The 3D-printed grid-like electrodes can increase the contact area with the electrolyte and shorten the ion transport distance [48,49]. Fig. 6 (a) illustrates the schematic diagram of the battery assembled with 3D-printed (3DP) Ti3C2T x /SnS/S. Fig. 6(b) demonstrates the advantages offered by 3D-printed electrodes. Fig. S18(a, b) shows the diagrams of Ti3C2T x /SnS/S as 3D-printed electrodes with a 7 mm × 7 mm grid. Fig. 6(c) displays the SEM image of the square grid in the printed electrode. Measurements indicate that the diameter of the 3D-printed columnar lines is 0.45 mm, with a side length of 0.57 mm for the square spaces. Therefore, the area of the 3D-printed electrode is calculated to be 33 mm2. Upon closer examination of the 3D-printed columnar lines (Fig. 6d and Fig. S19a, b), numerous pores can be observed. These abundant pores are formed due to the freeze-drying process of the electrodes. The large voids and numerous pores can significantly enhance the penetration of electrolytes and shorten the diffusion paths for ions and electrons. Fig. S20 shows that the 3DP Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode exhibits an initial capacity of 852.3 mAh g−1 at a sulfur loading of 3.1 mg cm−2 and 1 C, and remains 430.4 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. Fig. 6(e) displays the cycling performance of the 3DP Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode. 3DP Ti3C2T x /SnS/S exhibits an initial areal capacity of 15.0 mAh cm−2 with a high loading of 12.7 mg cm−2 at 0.05 C. The 3D-printed cathode experiences a decline in capacity during the first 10 cycles due to the decomposition of LiNO3, but it is then stabilized and delivers a capacity of 8.9 mAh cm−2 over 70 cycles. A comparison of 3DP Ti3C2T x /SnS/S with other recently reported coated and 3DP electrodes with high loadings is presented in Table S3. Among these coated and 3D-printed electrodes, 3DP Ti3C2T x /SnS/S demonstrates significant advantages in terms of sulfur loading and areal-specific capacity. The excellent performance at high loading further confirms that the built-in electric field and heterostructure promote the bidirectional catalytic conversion of sulfur species, which inhibits the LiPSs shuttling and enhances sulfur utilization in LSBs. Fig. 6(f) presents the LiPSs adsorption and catalytic conversion mechanism in the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure. The adsorption and catalytic properties of individual Ti3C2T x and SnS materials are limited. By combining Ti3C2T x and SnS to construct a Mott-Schottky heterojunction and creating a built-in electric field directed from Ti3C2T x to SnS within the heterostructure, the charge transfer rate is significantly accelerated. Meanwhile, the constructed heterointerface enhances the adsorption and catalytic properties of LiPSs, while the 3D porous conductive structure facilitates sulfur loading and compensates for the low conductivity of sulfur. The synergistic effect of the built-in electric field and heterogeneous interface significantly accelerates the sulfur reduction kinetics and improves electrochemical performance. Additionally, the solid-liquid-solid (S8-LiPSs-Li2S) conversion rate is effectively enhanced, further speeding up the kinetics of the entire electrochemical reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a 3D porous Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterostructure with a built-in electric field, enhancing sulfur utilization in LSBs. This heterostructure can facilitate sulfur loading, mitigate volume expansion, and increase active site exposure. The built-in electric field promotes charge transfer and ion diffusion, effectively preventing LiPSs dissolution and reducing the shuttle effect. Additionally, the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterostructure accelerates LiPSs migration, enhancing electrocatalytic activity and sulfur reduction reaction kinetics. A 3D-printed Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode with a sulfur loading of 12.7 mg cm−2 is manufactured using 3D printing technology, achieving an areal-specific capacity of 15.0 mAh cm−2. This research provides valuable insights into the application of Mott-Schottky heterojunction and 3D printing technology in high-performance LSBs. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) offer high energy density and low cost but face challenges such as low sulfur utilization, lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) shuttling, and limited reaction kinetics. To address these issues, we rationally design a Ti3C2T x /SnS Mott-Schottky heterostructure with a built-in electric field. This three-dimensional (3D) porous architecture can enhance sulfur loading, facilitate electrolyte penetration, and expose more adsorption and catalytic sites. More importantly, the built-in electric field facilitates charge transfer and directs LiPSs migration from SnS to Ti3C2T x . The oriented migration of LiPSs enables rapid catalytic conversion at the Ti3C2T x /SnS heterogeneous interface, enhancing electrocatalytic activity and sulfur reduction reaction kinetics. The Ti3C2T x /SnS/S cathode achieves a high initial capacity (1367.1 mAh g−1), excellent rate performance (602.7 mAh g−1 at 3 C), and stable long cycling performance with an average capacity decay rate of only 0.029% per cycle at 2 C. Additionally, a high-sulfur-loaded 3D-printed cathode with loading of 12.7 mg cm−2 manufactured using 3D printing exhibits an areal capacity of 15.0 mAh cm−2, retaining 8.9 mAh cm−2 after 70 cycles.
